projectDesc.p: "The Song of Peter" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.
Abbreviations in the Old High German text are expanded, spelling and punctuation otherwise follow the manuscript.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: ﻿Unsar trohtin hat farsalt sancte petre giuualt daz er mac ginerian
app.rdg: Our Lord gave Saint Peter the power to save

app.lem: ze imo dingenten man. kyrie eleyson christe eleyson.
app.rdg: those entrusted to him. Kyrie eleison. Christe eleison.

app.lem: Er hapet ouh mit vuortun himriches portun. dar in mach er skerian
app.rdg: With words, he also guards the gates of heaven through which he admits

app.lem: den er uuili nerian. kirie eleison criste [eleyson]
app.rdg:
those whom he wishes to save. Kyrie eleison. Christe eleison.
Peter’s words can possibly be understood as the key to the gates of Heaven. According to Haug (1991), p.1119, this idea is present in other Latin hymns.

app.lem: Pittemes den gotes trut alla samant uparlut. daz er uns firtanen giuuer
app.rdg: Let us entreat God’s disciple, loudly and in unison, so that he grants

app.lem:
do ginaden
This verse can also be found in Otfrid’s Gospel Harmony (I7,28), but with the Frankish form 'ginadon which results in an assonance instead of a rhyme.
. kirie eleyson criste eleyson
app.rdg: mercy to us sinners. Kyrie eleison. Christe eleison.
